questions.question_text: What is meant by the term 'universal solvent' in the context of water?

options.label: A
options.text: Water can dissolve only organic compounds.

options.label: B
options.text: Water can dissolve a wide variety of substances, including many solids, gases, and liquids.

options.label: C
options.text: Water is the only liquid that can act as a solvent.

options.label: D
options.text: Water loses its solvent properties when heated.

questions.key_concept: Water's ability to dissolve many substances due to its high dielectric constant.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a reason why water is considered a universal solvent?

options.label: A
options.text: It has a high dielectric constant.

options.label: B
options.text: It reduces the force of attraction between ions.

options.label: C
options.text: It dissolves only ionic compounds.

options.label: D
options.text: It can dissolve gases and other liquids.

questions.key_concept: Water dissolves many types of substances, not just ionic ones.

questions.question_text: A student says, 'Distilled water stored in a sealed glass bottle leaves etchings because water is a poor solvent.' What is the flaw in this reasoning?

options.label: A
options.text: Distilled water is pure and cannot cause etchings.

options.label: B
options.text: The etchings prove water is a good solvent, as even glass dissolves in traces over time.

options.label: C
options.text: Etchings are caused by impurities in the glass, not by water.

options.label: D
options.text: Only tap water can act as a solvent, not distilled water.

questions.key_concept: Water's solvent property is so effective that it can dissolve traces of glass.

questions.question_text: In an experiment to show tap water contains dissolved solids, water is evaporated from a watch glass. What would be observed if rainwater was used instead of tap water?

options.label: A
options.text: Concentric rings of solid matter would form.

options.label: B
options.text: No concentric rings would be left on the watch glass.

options.label: C
options.text: The watch glass would crack due to impurities.

options.label: D
options.text: Coloured rings would form due to dissolved gases.

questions.key_concept: Rainwater and distilled water lack dissolved solids that leave a residue on evaporation.

questions.question_text: How does the composition of air dissolved in water differ from ordinary atmospheric air?

options.label: A
options.text: It has a lower percentage of oxygen and a higher percentage of nitrogen.

options.label: B
options.text: It has a higher percentage of oxygen and a lower percentage of nitrogen.

options.label: C
options.text: It contains no carbon dioxide, unlike atmospheric air.

options.label: D
options.text: Its composition is identical to atmospheric air.

questions.key_concept: Oxygen is more soluble in water than nitrogen, enriching the dissolved air with oxygen.

questions.question_text: Why is the presence of dissolved air in water crucial for aquatic life?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides nitrogen for fish to breathe.

options.label: B
options.text: The dissolved oxygen is used by aquatic animals for respiration, and dissolved carbon dioxide is used by plants for photosynthesis.

options.label: C
options.text: It increases the density of water, making it easier for plants to float.

options.label: D
options.text: It prevents water from freezing by lowering its boiling point.

questions.key_concept: Biological importance of dissolved gases (O2 for respiration, CO2 for photosynthesis).

concepts.concept_name: Physical Properties of Water (Density & Anomalous Expansion)

questions.question_text: At what temperature does pure water have its maximum density?
questions.key_concept: Water has maximum density (1 g/cm³) at 4°C.

questions.question_text: What is the term for the property where water expands below 4°C upon cooling?

options.label: A
options.text: Normal contraction

options.label: B
options.text: Anomalous expansion

options.label: C
options.text: Thermal inflation

options.label: D
options.text: Latent expansion

questions.key_concept: Anomalous expansion of water.

questions.question_text: A student states, 'Ice sinks in water because it is solid.' Why is this statement incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Ice is less dense than water, so it floats.

options.label: B
options.text: Ice is more dense than water, but surface tension holds it up.

options.label: C
options.text: Ice sinks only in salt water, not in pure water.

options.label: D
options.text: The statement is correct; all solids sink in their liquid forms.

questions.key_concept: Water expands on freezing, making ice less dense (0.92 g/cm³) than liquid water.

questions.question_text: Why does the anomalous expansion of water enable marine life to survive in cold regions?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes water to boil at a lower temperature, releasing heat.

options.label: B
options.text: It causes ice to form at the bottom of ponds, insulating the surface.

options.label: C
options.text: It causes ice to form as a layer on top, insulating the liquid water below where life exists.

options.label: D
options.text: It increases the salt concentration of water, lowering its freezing point.

questions.key_concept: Ice floats due to lower density, forming an insulating layer on top.

questions.question_text: How does the density of water at 0°C compare to its density at 10°C?

options.label: A
options.text: Water at 0°C is denser than water at 10°C.

options.label: B
options.text: Water at 10°C is denser than water at 0°C.

options.label: C
options.text: Water has the same density at both temperatures.

options.label: D
options.text: The density comparison depends on the pressure, not just temperature.

questions.key_concept: Density increases as water cools from 10°C to 4°C, then decreases from 4°C to 0°C.

questions.question_text: Why do lakes and rivers not freeze suddenly from the bottom up in winter?

options.label: A
options.text: Because water at the bottom is under high pressure, preventing freezing.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the high specific latent heat of solidification releases heat slowly.

options.label: C
options.text: Because sunlight penetrates to the bottom, keeping it warm.

options.label: D
options.text: Because dissolved salts increase the density of bottom water, raising its freezing point.

questions.key_concept: Latent heat of fusion/solidification moderates temperature change during freezing.

concepts.concept_name: Latent Heat of Fusion and Vaporization

questions.question_text: What is the specific latent heat of fusion of ice?

options.label: A
options.text: 80 cal/g

options.label: B
options.text: 100 cal/g

options.label: C
options.text: 540 cal/g

options.label: D
options.text: 1 cal/g

questions.key_concept: Latent heat of fusion of ice is 336 J/g or 80 cal/g.

questions.question_text: The energy required to change 1g of water at 100°C to steam at 100°C is called:

options.label: A
options.text: Specific heat capacity

options.label: B
options.text: Latent heat of fusion

options.label: C
options.text: Latent heat of vaporization

options.label: D
options.text: Heat of condensation

questions.key_concept: Definition of latent heat of vaporization (2268 J/g or 540 cal/g).

questions.question_text: A student reasons, 'Steam at 100°C causes more severe burns than water at 100°C because steam is hotter.' What is the key scientific reason this explanation is incomplete?

options.label: A
options.text: Steam is actually cooler than boiling water.

options.label: B
options.text: Steam releases its high latent heat of condensation when it touches the skin, transferring more energy.

options.label: C
options.text: Water at 100°C has a higher specific heat capacity than steam.

options.label: D
options.text: Steam burns are worse only because they cover a larger area.

questions.key_concept: Severity of steam burns is due to the release of latent heat of condensation.

questions.question_text: Why is water used as a coolant in car radiators and desert coolers?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is easily available and cheap.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it has a low specific heat capacity, so it heats up quickly.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it has a high specific heat capacity, so it absorbs a lot of heat without a large temperature rise.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it has a high latent heat of fusion, so it remains liquid over a wide range.

questions.key_concept: Application of water's high specific heat capacity (4.2 J/g/°C).

questions.question_text: How do the latent heat of fusion of ice and the latent heat of vaporization of water compare in terms of energy per gram?

options.label: A
options.text: They are equal.

options.label: B
options.text: The latent heat of vaporization is much greater.

options.label: C
options.text: The latent heat of fusion is much greater.

options.label: D
options.text: The comparison depends on the pressure.

questions.key_concept: Latent heat of vaporization (540 cal/g) > Latent heat of fusion (80 cal/g).

questions.question_text: Why does the release of latent heat of condensation cause the violence associated with torrential rain?

options.label: A
options.text: The heat release causes rapid evaporation, creating strong winds.

options.label: B
options.text: The sudden release of a large amount of heat energy fuels powerful upward air currents and storm intensity.

options.label: C
options.text: The heat melts hail stones instantly, causing flash floods.

options.label: D
options.text: The heat increases the pressure, which stops the rain from falling.

questions.key_concept: Link between latent heat release and meteorological phenomena.

questions.question_text: In a sugar solution, which component is the solvent?

options.label: A
options.text: Sugar

options.label: B
options.text: Water

options.label: C
options.text: Both sugar and water are solvents.

options.label: D
options.text: Air

questions.key_concept: Solvent is the medium in which solute dissolves; for liquid solutions, it's the liquid component.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a characteristic of a true solution?

options.label: A
options.text: It scatters light (Tyndall effect).

options.label: B
options.text: It is a heterogeneous mixture.

options.label: C
options.text: The solute particles are about 10^-10 m in size.

options.label: D
options.text: Its components can be separated by filtration.

questions.key_concept: True solutions are homogeneous, have very small particles, and do not scatter light.

questions.question_text: A student labels a mixture of sand and water as a 'solution.' Why is this incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Because sand is not a solid.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a heterogeneous mixture where particles settle and can be filtered, unlike a true solution.

options.label: C
options.text: Because water cannot act as a solvent for sand.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a compound, not a mixture.

questions.key_concept: Distinguishing a suspension (sand+water) from a true solution.

questions.question_text: In brass, which is a solid solution of copper and zinc, which metal is the solvent?

options.label: A
options.text: Zinc, because it is added to copper.

options.label: B
options.text: Copper, because it is present in larger proportion (70%).

options.label: C
options.text: Neither; solid solutions do not have solvents.

options.label: D
options.text: Zinc, because it has a lower melting point.

questions.key_concept: In solid solutions (alloys), the component in excess is the solvent.

questions.question_text: How does an aqueous solution differ from a non-aqueous solution?

options.label: A
options.text: Aqueous solutions are always dilute, while non-aqueous are concentrated.

options.label: B
options.text: Aqueous solutions use water as the solvent, while non-aqueous solutions use other liquids like alcohol or petrol.

options.label: C
options.text: Aqueous solutions contain only ionic solutes, while non-aqueous contain covalent solutes.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no difference; the terms are interchangeable.

questions.key_concept: Definition based on the nature of the solvent.

questions.question_text: Why is tincture of iodine considered a non-aqueous solution?

options.label: A
options.text: Because iodine is a solid.

options.label: B
options.text: Because its solvent is alcohol, not water.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is used for external application only.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a saturated solution.

questions.key_concept: Classification of solutions based on the solvent used.

questions.question_text: A solution in which no more solute can be dissolved at a given temperature is called:

options.label: A
options.text: Unsaturated solution

options.label: B
options.text: Saturated solution

options.label: C
options.text: Supersaturated solution

options.label: D
options.text: Concentrated solution

questions.key_concept: Definition of a saturated solution.

questions.question_text: Which of the following can be done to change a saturated solution into an unsaturated one without changing the temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: Add more solute

options.label: B
options.text: Add more solvent

options.label: C
options.text: Cool the solution

options.label: D
options.text: Heat the solution

questions.key_concept: Adding solvent dilutes a saturated solution, making it unsaturated.

questions.question_text: A student prepares a supersaturated solution of potassium nitrate and then adds a small crystal of KNO3 to it. What is the most likely immediate outcome?

options.label: A
options.text: The added crystal will dissolve rapidly.

options.label: C
options.text: The temperature of the solution will drop sharply.

options.label: B
options.text: Excess solute will rapidly crystallize out of the solution.

options.label: D
options.text: The solution will become unsaturated.

questions.key_concept: Supersaturated solutions are unstable; adding a seed crystal triggers crystallization.

questions.question_text: If a saturated solution of a salt is cooled, what generally happens?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes unsaturated.

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes more concentrated.

options.label: C
options.text: Some solute crystallizes out, leaving a saturated solution at the lower temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: The solubility increases, so no change occurs.

questions.key_concept: Solubility of most solids decreases with temperature, causing precipitation on cooling.

questions.question_text: How does a supersaturated solution differ from a saturated solution at the same temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: It contains less solute per unit solvent.

options.label: B
options.text: It contains more solute per unit solvent than the saturated solution.

options.label: C
options.text: It is always hot, while a saturated solution is at room temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: It is heterogeneous, while a saturated solution is homogeneous.

questions.key_concept: Supersaturated solution holds solute in excess of its normal solubility at that temperature.

questions.question_text: Why must a supersaturated solution be prepared carefully, without impurities or physical disturbance?

options.label: A
options.text: To prevent the solute from reacting with the solvent.

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent the solute from oxidizing in air.

options.label: C
options.text: Because impurities or disturbance can act as nucleation sites, causing spontaneous crystallization.

options.label: D
options.text: To ensure the solution boils at a constant temperature.

questions.key_concept: Conditions for maintaining the metastable state of a supersaturated solution.

questions.question_text: What is meant by the 'solubility' of a solute in water at a given temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: The mass of solvent required to dissolve 1g of solute.

options.label: B
options.text: The maximum mass of solute (in grams) that can saturate 100g of solvent at that temperature.

options.label: C
options.text: The volume of solution formed when solute is dissolved.

options.label: D
options.text: The time taken for a solute to dissolve completely.

questions.key_concept: Definition of solubility.

questions.question_text: Which factor does NOT increase the rate of solubility of a solid in a liquid?

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the temperature

options.label: B
options.text: Stirring the mixture

options.label: C
options.text: Using larger solute particles

options.label: D
options.text: Crushing the solute into a powder

questions.key_concept: Smaller particle size increases surface area and rate of dissolution.

questions.question_text: A student observes that sugar dissolves faster in hot tea than in iced tea and concludes, 'The solubility of sugar is lower at higher temperatures.' Why is this conclusion wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: The observation is incorrect; sugar dissolves faster in cold liquids.

options.label: B
options.text: The rate of dissolving is faster, but the conclusion confuses 'rate' with the maximum 'amount' (solubility) that can dissolve, which usually increases with temperature.

options.label: C
options.text: Sugar is an exception; its solubility decreases with temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: Tea contains other substances that affect solubility.

questions.key_concept: Distinguishing between the rate of dissolution and the solubility (maximum amount).

questions.question_text: According to Henry's Law, how does pressure affect the solubility of a gas in a liquid?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased pressure decreases gas solubility.

options.label: B
options.text: Increased pressure increases gas solubility proportionally.

options.label: C
options.text: Pressure has no effect on gas solubility.

options.label: D
options.text: Increased pressure only affects the solubility of oxygen, not other gases.

questions.key_concept: Henry's Law: Solubility of a gas is directly proportional to the pressure on the liquid surface.

questions.question_text: How does the effect of temperature on the solubility of most solids compare with its effect on the solubility of gases in water?

options.label: A
options.text: Solubility of both solids and gases increases with temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: Solubility of solids usually increases, while solubility of gases decreases with increasing temperature.

options.label: C
options.text: Solubility of solids decreases, while solubility of gases increases with increasing temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: Temperature has no significant effect on either.

questions.key_concept: Opposite trends for solubility of solids (endothermic) vs. gases (exothermic) in water.

questions.question_text: Why does boiled water taste 'flat' compared to tap water?

options.label: A
options.text: Boiling removes dissolved solids that add taste.

options.label: B
options.text: Boiling drives off dissolved gases (like air and CO2) that contribute to the taste.

options.label: C
options.text: Boiling concentrates harmful impurities, affecting taste.

options.label: D
options.text: The heat causes a chemical change in the water molecules.

questions.key_concept: Effect of temperature on gas solubility and its relation to taste.

questions.question_text: What is plotted on the Y-axis of a typical solubility curve?

options.label: A
options.text: Temperature

options.label: B
options.text: Solubility (grams of solute per 100g solvent)

options.label: C
options.text: Volume of solution

options.label: D
options.text: Pressure

questions.key_concept: Understanding the axes of a solubility curve.

questions.question_text: From a solubility curve, what can you directly determine?

options.label: A
options.text: The colour of the saturated solution.

options.label: B
options.text: The mass of solute needed to make a saturated solution in 100g water at a specific temperature.

options.label: C
options.text: The rate at which the solute dissolves.

options.label: D
options.text: The pH of the solution.

questions.key_concept: Purpose of a solubility curve.

questions.question_text: A student looks at a solubility curve showing a line that rises steeply. He concludes the substance's solubility is not affected by temperature. Why is this conclusion incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: A steeply rising line indicates a strong decrease in solubility with temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: A steeply rising line indicates a strong increase in solubility with temperature, not no effect.

options.label: C
options.text: All solubility curves are horizontal lines.

options.label: D
options.text: The slope of the curve indicates the colour change, not solubility change.

questions.key_concept: Interpreting the slope of a solubility curve.

questions.question_text: Using a solubility curve, how would you find if a solution at 40°C containing 50g of solute in 100g water is saturated?

options.label: A
options.text: Check if the point (40°C, 50g) lies on the curve for that substance. If it's on the line, it's saturated.

options.label: B
options.text: Check if the solute is solid or liquid.

options.label: C
options.text: Heat the solution and see if more dissolves.

options.label: D
options.text: Compare the density of the solution with pure water.

questions.key_concept: Using the curve to determine saturation status.

questions.question_text: Based on typical solubility curves, which salt's solubility is least affected by a temperature increase from 20°C to 60°C?

options.label: A
options.text: Potassium nitrate (KNO3)

options.label: B
options.text: Sodium chloride (NaCl)

options.label: C
options.text: Potassium bromide (KBr)

options.label: D
options.text: Calcium sulphate (CaSO4.2H2O)

questions.key_concept: NaCl's solubility curve is relatively flat compared to others.

questions.question_text: Why does the solubility curve for Na2SO4.10H2O (Glauber's salt) show a decrease after 32.8°C?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the hydrated salt loses all its water of crystallization and becomes anhydrous Na2SO4, which has different solubility behaviour.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the solution becomes supersaturated automatically at that temperature.

options.label: C
options.text: Because water starts to evaporate rapidly above that temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: It is an error in the graph; solubility always increases with temperature.

questions.key_concept: Anomalous solubility due to change in hydration state of the solute.

questions.question_text: What is 'water of crystallisation'?

options.label: A
options.text: Water molecules trapped mechanically between crystals.

options.label: B
options.text: The fixed amount of water molecules chemically combined in a definite proportion within the crystal structure of a hydrated salt.

options.label: C
options.text: Water used to wash crystals after preparation.

options.label: D
options.text: Water present as impurities in a sample.

questions.key_concept: Definition of water of crystallisation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a hydrated salt?

options.label: A
options.text: Sodium chloride (NaCl)

options.label: B
options.text: Copper sulphate pentahydrate (CuSO4.5H2O)

options.label: C
options.text: Potassium nitrate (KNO3)

options.label: D
options.text: Sugar (C12H22O11)

questions.key_concept: Identifying hydrated substances from their formulas.

questions.question_text: When blue crystals of CuSO4.5H2O are heated strongly, they turn white. A student says the white powder is 'dried CuSO4.5H2O'. What is the correct description?

options.label: A
options.text: The student is correct; heating just removes surface moisture.

options.label: B
options.text: The white powder is anhydrous copper sulphate (CuSO4); the water of crystallisation has been driven off.

options.label: C
options.text: The white powder is copper oxide (CuO) formed by decomposition.

options.label: D
options.text: The colour change is due to a change in crystal shape, not loss of water.

questions.key_concept: Heating a hydrated salt yields the anhydrous salt, not a 'dried' version of the hydrate.

questions.question_text: What is observed when a few drops of water are added to the white anhydrous copper sulphate obtained by heating the blue crystals?

options.label: A
options.text: It dissolves without any colour change.

options.label: B
options.text: It turns blue again and may become warm.

options.label: C
options.text: It releases a gas.

options.label: D
options.text: It turns black.

questions.key_concept: Reversible nature of hydration/dehydration; exothermic rehydration.

questions.question_text: How does an anhydrous substance differ from a hygroscopic substance?

options.label: A
options.text: Anhydrous substances contain no water, while hygroscopic substances absorb moisture from air.

options.label: B
options.text: Anhydrous substances are always liquid, while hygroscopic are solid.

options.label: C
options.text: Anhydrous substances release water on heating, while hygroscopic substances do not.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no difference; the terms are synonyms.

questions.key_concept: Distinguishing between a state (anhydrous) and a property (hygroscopic).

questions.question_text: Why must crystals of a hydrated salt not be heated too strongly when drying them?

options.label: A
options.text: Strong heating may decompose the salt or drive off the water of crystallisation, resulting in a powder instead of crystals.

options.label: B
options.text: Strong heating always makes them melt, losing their shape.

options.label: C
options.text: Strong heating makes them absorb more moisture from the air.

options.label: D
options.text: Strong heating is necessary to get perfectly dry crystals.

questions.key_concept: Practical aspect of preparing hydrated crystals.

questions.question_text: What is efflorescence?

options.label: A
options.text: Absorption of moisture from air to form a solution.

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of water of crystallisation when exposed to dry air, turning crystals to powder.

options.label: C
options.text: Formation of crystals from a solution.

options.label: D
options.text: Release of water vapour on heating.

questions.key_concept: Definition of efflorescence.

questions.question_text: Which substance is an example of a deliquescent substance?

options.label: A
options.text: Washing soda crystals (Na2CO3.10H2O)

options.label: B
options.text: Calcium chloride (CaCl2)

options.label: C
options.text: Common salt (NaCl)

options.label: D
options.text: Blue vitriol (CuSO4.5H2O)

questions.key_concept: Identifying deliquescent substances.

questions.question_text: A student finds that table salt (NaCl) becomes sticky in the rainy season. He concludes pure NaCl is deliquescent. Why is this conclusion not entirely accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Pure NaCl is not deliquescent; the stickiness is due to impurities like MgCl2 or CaCl2 which are deliquescent.

options.label: B
options.text: Pure NaCl is highly deliquescent, so the conclusion is accurate.

options.label: C
options.text: The stickiness is due to efflorescence, not deliquescence.

options.label: D
options.text: All salts become sticky in the rainy season.

questions.key_concept: Commercial table salt vs. pure sodium chloride; role of impurities.

questions.question_text: In which condition would efflorescence occur most rapidly?

options.label: A
options.text: Cold, humid air

options.label: B
options.text: Hot, dry air

options.label: C
options.text: Under water

options.label: D
options.text: Inside a sealed container

questions.key_concept: Factors affecting efflorescence (temperature and humidity).

questions.question_text: How does deliquescence differ from hygroscopy?

options.label: A
options.text: Hygroscopic substances absorb moisture and become wet or dissolve; deliquescent substances only become damp.

options.label: B
options.text: Deliquescent substances absorb enough moisture to dissolve and form a solution; hygroscopic substances absorb moisture but may not necessarily dissolve.

options.label: C
options.text: Deliquescence involves loss of water, hygroscopy involves gain of water.

options.label: D
options.text: They are the same phenomenon with different names.

questions.key_concept: Deliquescence is an extreme form of hygroscopy leading to dissolution.

questions.question_text: Why is concentrated sulphuric acid kept in sealed bottles?

options.label: A
options.text: To prevent it from reacting with glass.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is hygroscopic and will absorb moisture from air, becoming diluted.

options.label: C
options.text: To prevent it from efflorescing.

options.label: D
options.text: To stop it from decomposing in sunlight.

questions.key_concept: Hygroscopic nature of conc. H2SO4 and its practical storage.

questions.question_text: What is a drying agent (desiccant)?

options.label: A
options.text: A substance that adds water to compounds.

options.label: B
options.text: A substance that absorbs moisture from other substances without chemically reacting with them.

options.label: C
options.text: A substance that removes chemically combined water.

options.label: D
options.text: A substance that causes efflorescence.

questions.key_concept: Definition of a drying/desiccating agent.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is commonly used as a drying agent in a desiccator?

options.label: A
options.text: Sodium chloride

options.label: B
options.text: Anhydrous calcium chloride

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrated copper sulphate

options.label: D
options.text: Potassium nitrate

questions.key_concept: Common drying agents.

questions.question_text: A student uses quicklime (CaO) to dry ammonia gas (NH3). Another student says this is wrong because CaO is basic and will react with NH3. Is the second student correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, a base (CaO) will react with a base (NH3).

options.label: B
options.text: No, quicklime is suitable because it is a basic drying agent and will not react with the basic gas ammonia.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, CaO is a dehydrating agent, not a drying agent.

options.label: D
options.text: No, all drying agents work for all gases.

questions.key_concept: Choice of drying agent must not react chemically with the substance being dried.

questions.question_text: Conc. H2SO4 can be used to dry HCl gas but not NH3 gas. Why?

options.label: A
options.text: HCl is acidic and will not react with the acid H2SO4, while NH3 is basic and will react with it.

options.label: B
options.text: HCl is a reducing agent and H2SO4 is an oxidizing agent, so they react.

options.label: C
options.text: NH3 is lighter than air, so it cannot be dried.

options.label: D
options.text: Conc. H2SO4 absorbs NH3 faster than it absorbs water.

questions.key_concept: Chemical compatibility between drying agent and substance.

questions.question_text: How does a drying agent differ from a dehydrating agent?

options.label: A
options.text: Drying agents remove physically absorbed water; dehydrating agents remove chemically combined water (elements of H and O in 2:1 ratio).

options.label: B
options.text: Drying agents are used for solids, dehydrating agents for liquids.

options.label: C
options.text: Drying agents cause chemical changes, dehydrating agents cause physical changes.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no difference; the terms are synonyms.

questions.key_concept: Drying agent vs. dehydrating agent based on the type of water removed and the change involved.

questions.question_text: Why is fused calcium chloride (CaCl2) preferred over the hydrated form as a drying agent in a desiccator?

options.label: A
options.text: Fused CaCl2 is anhydrous and has a strong affinity for water, whereas the hydrated form is already saturated with water.

options.label: B
options.text: Fused CaCl2 is cheaper.

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrated CaCl2 reacts with the substances kept in the desiccator.

options.label: D
options.text: Fused CaCl2 is a dehydrating agent, which is more effective.

questions.key_concept: Drying agents must be anhydrous to be effective.

questions.question_text: Water is classified as 'soft' based on its reaction with what substance?

options.label: A
options.text: Litmus paper

options.label: B
options.text: Soap

options.label: C
options.text: Washing soda

options.label: D
options.text: Lime

questions.key_concept: Definition of soft water: readily forms lather with soap.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of naturally soft water?

options.label: A
options.text: Well water

options.label: B
options.text: River water

options.label: C
options.text: Rainwater

options.label: D
options.text: Spring water

questions.key_concept: Rainwater and distilled water are soft.

questions.question_text: A student says, 'Hard water is unfit for drinking because it contains harmful minerals.' Is this a correct statement regarding the common definition of hardness?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, hard water is defined as being poisonous.

options.label: B
options.text: No, hard water is defined by its reaction with soap (forming scum), not necessarily by being harmful to drink. In fact, it contains useful minerals like calcium.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, only soft water is safe to drink.

options.label: D
options.text: No, all natural water is soft water.

questions.key_concept: Definition of hard water is based on soap reaction, not health effects.

questions.question_text: What is observed when soap is added to hard water?

options.label: A
options.text: It forms a rich, permanent lather immediately.

options.label: B
options.text: It forms a white, insoluble precipitate (scum) before lather forms.

options.label: C
options.text: It turns the water milky without any precipitate.

options.label: D
options.text: It causes effervescence due to CO2 release.

questions.key_concept: Formation of soap scum (calcium/magnesium stearate) with hard water.

questions.question_text: How does the taste of soft water compare to that of hard water?

options.label: A
options.text: Soft water has a more pleasant taste due to dissolved salts.

options.label: B
options.text: Soft water (like distilled water) tastes flat, while hard water has a better taste due to dissolved minerals.

options.label: C
options.text: Both taste exactly the same.

options.label: D
options.text: Soft water tastes salty, while hard water tastes sweet.

questions.key_concept: Advantage of hard water: pleasant taste due to dissolved matter.

questions.question_text: Why is hard water considered advantageous for use in lead pipes?

options.label: A
options.text: It forms an insoluble layer of lead sulphate on the pipe interior, preventing lead poisoning of water.

options.label: B
options.text: It dissolves the lead pipe, making the water flow faster.

options.label: C
options.text: It softens the lead pipe over time.

options.label: D
options.text: Hard water has no advantage; it corrodes lead pipes faster.

questions.key_concept: Hard water prevents lead poisoning by forming an insoluble coating.

questions.question_text: What ions are primarily responsible for causing hardness in water?

options.label: A
options.text: Sodium and Potassium ions

options.label: B
options.text: Calcium and Magnesium ions

options.label: C
options.text: Chloride and Sulphate ions

options.label: D
options.text: Carbonate and Bicarbonate ions

questions.key_concept: Hardness is caused by dissolved salts of calcium and magnesium.

questions.question_text: Temporary hardness is caused by the presence of:

options.label: A
options.text: Chlorides of calcium and magnesium

options.label: B
options.text: Sulphates of calcium and magnesium

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrogen carbonates (bicarbonates) of calcium and magnesium

options.label: D
options.text: Nitrates of calcium and magnesium

questions.key_concept: Cause of temporary hardness.

questions.question_text: A student tests a water sample. On boiling, some precipitate forms and the water becomes softer. He concludes the water had only permanent hardness. What is wrong with this conclusion?

options.label: A
options.text: Boiling removes permanent hardness, not temporary hardness.

options.label: B
options.text: The observation indicates the presence of temporary hardness (removed by boiling), not necessarily only permanent hardness.

options.label: C
options.text: Boiling makes all hard water softer, regardless of type.

options.label: D
options.text: Precipitate formation indicates the water was soft to begin with.

questions.key_concept: Temporary hardness is removed by boiling; permanent hardness is not.

questions.question_text: How are stalactites and stalagmites in limestone caves related to water hardness?

options.label: A
options.text: They are formed by the deposition of calcium carbonate from hard water containing calcium bicarbonate.

options.label: B
options.text: They are formed by the evaporation of soft water.

options.label: C
options.text: They are made of sodium chloride deposited from sea water.

options.label: D
options.text: They are caused by the freezing of hard water in cold caves.

questions.key_concept: Natural phenomenon illustrating the reversible reaction involving temporary hardness.

questions.question_text: How does the cause of permanent hardness differ from that of temporary hardness?

options.label: A
options.text: Permanent: Chlorides/Sulphates of Ca/Mg; Temporary: Bicarbonates of Ca/Mg.

options.label: B
options.text: Permanent: Bicarbonates of Ca/Mg; Temporary: Chlorides/Sulphates of Ca/Mg.

options.label: C
options.text: Permanent: caused by sodium salts; Temporary: caused by potassium salts.

options.label: D
options.text: Both are caused by the same salts, but in different concentrations.

questions.key_concept: Distinguishing salts causing temporary vs. permanent hardness.

questions.question_text: Why is water that flows over gypsum (CaSO4.2H2O) beds permanently hard?

options.label: A
options.text: Because gypsum dissolves to give calcium sulphate, a salt whose hardness cannot be removed by boiling.

options.label: B
options.text: Because gypsum decomposes to give calcium bicarbonate, causing temporary hardness.

options.label: C
options.text: Because gypsum absorbs all the calcium ions from water.

options.label: D
options.text: Because gypsum is a soft mineral and does not affect water.

questions.key_concept: Permanent hardness caused by calcium/magnesium sulphates.

questions.question_text: What is the main disadvantage of using hard water in boilers?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes the boiler walls transparent.

options.label: B
options.text: It causes the formation of boiler scale (insoluble deposits) on the inner walls.

options.label: C
options.text: It makes the water boil at a lower temperature, wasting fuel.

options.label: D
options.text: It produces explosive gases.

questions.key_concept: Boiler scaling is a primary disadvantage.

questions.question_text: The insoluble precipitate formed when soap is used with hard water is called:

options.label: A
options.text: Lather

options.label: B
options.text: Scum or soap curd

options.label: C
options.text: Fur

options.label: D
options.text: Scale

questions.key_concept: Term for the precipitate formed by soap and hard water.

questions.question_text: Why is boiler scale formation economically disadvantageous? A student says, 'It only makes cleaning difficult.' What other key point is missed?

options.label: A
options.text: Scale is a good conductor of heat, improving efficiency.

options.label: B
options.text: Scale is a bad conductor of heat, wasting fuel, and can lead to boiler explosions by blocking tubes and increasing pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: Scale makes the water taste better.

options.label: D
options.text: Scale prevents corrosion, which is an advantage.

questions.key_concept: Multiple disadvantages of scale: poor heat conduction and safety hazard.

questions.question_text: What is the 'fur' found in kettles used to boil hard water?

options.label: A
options.text: Iron oxide rust

options.label: B
options.text: Insoluble carbonates of calcium and magnesium deposited from temporary hardness.

options.label: C
options.text: Soap curd from washing the kettle.

options.label: D
options.text: A layer of algae growth.

questions.key_concept: Domestic example of scale/fur formation from temporary hardness.

questions.question_text: How does the problem caused by hard water in washing differ from its problem in boilers?

options.label: A
options.text: Washing: Forms scum, wastes soap; Boilers: Forms scale, wastes fuel, causes safety risks.

options.label: B
options.text: Washing: Corrodes fabrics; Boilers: Improves heat transfer.

options.label: C
options.text: Both problems are identical, both involve scale formation.

options.label: D
options.text: Washing: Makes water boil faster; Boilers: Prevents lather formation.

questions.key_concept: Different disadvantages in different applications.

questions.question_text: Why do synthetic detergents overcome the washing problem associated with hard water, while soaps do not?

options.label: A
options.text: Detergents are not salts of fatty acids; their calcium/magnesium salts are soluble in water, so they don't form scum.

options.label: B
options.text: Detergents are more acidic and dissolve the scum.

options.label: C
options.text: Soaps are synthetic, detergents are natural.

options.label: D
options.text: Detergents react with hardness ions to soften the water first.

questions.key_concept: Chemical reason for detergent's advantage over soap in hard water.

questions.question_text: What is the simplest method to remove temporary hardness from water?

options.label: A
options.text: Adding washing soda

options.label: B
options.text: Boiling

options.label: C
options.text: Adding slaked lime

options.label: D
options.text: Using permutit

questions.key_concept: Boiling removes temporary hardness.

questions.question_text: Clark's process for removing temporary hardness involves adding:

options.label: A
options.text: Washing soda (Na2CO3)

options.label: B
options.text: Slaked lime [Ca(OH)2]

options.label: C
options.text: Common salt (NaCl)

options.label: D
options.text: Soap

questions.key_concept: Clark's process uses slaked lime.

questions.question_text: A student tries to soften temporary hard water by adding common salt (NaCl). Why will this method fail?

options.label: A
options.text: Common salt reacts with bicarbonates to form insoluble carbonates.

options.label: B
options.text: Common salt does not provide carbonate or hydroxide ions needed to precipitate calcium/magnesium ions.

options.label: C
options.text: Common salt makes the water permanently hard.

options.label: D
options.text: Common salt itself causes hardness.

questions.key_concept: Need for precipitating agents (CO3^2- or OH-) to remove Ca2+/Mg2+.

questions.question_text: What are the products formed when temporary hard water containing Ca(HCO3)2 is boiled?

options.label: A
options.text: CaCO3 (precipitate), H2O, and CO2 (gas)

options.label: B
options.text: Ca(OH)2 and CO2

options.label: C
options.text: CaSO4 and H2O

options.label: D
options.text: CaCl2 and H2O

questions.key_concept: Chemical equation for removal of temporary hardness by boiling.

questions.question_text: How does Clark's process (using lime) differ from the use of washing soda in removing temporary hardness?

options.label: A
options.text: Clark's process uses Ca(OH)2 and precipitates CaCO3; Washing soda uses Na2CO3 and also precipitates CaCO3/MgCO3.

options.label: B
options.text: Clark's process is for permanent hardness, washing soda for temporary.

options.label: C
options.text: Clark's process makes water acidic, washing soda makes it basic.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no difference in the final precipitate.

questions.key_concept: Different chemicals, same goal of precipitating Ca/Mg ions.

questions.question_text: Why is boiling not a practical large-scale method for removing temporary hardness, despite being simple?

options.label: A
options.text: It is costly and slow, requiring a lot of fuel to heat large volumes of water.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes the water toxic.

options.label: C
options.text: It removes permanent hardness as well, which is not always desired.

options.label: D
options.text: It requires complex machinery.

questions.key_concept: Economic and practical limitation of boiling for large quantities.

questions.question_text: Permanent hardness can be removed by adding:

options.label: A
options.text: Slaked lime only

options.label: B
options.text: Washing soda (sodium carbonate)

options.label: C
options.text: Boiling only

options.label: D
options.text: Common salt

questions.key_concept: Washing soda is used to remove permanent hardness.

questions.question_text: Which method is suitable for large-scale softening of water that may have both temporary and permanent hardness?

options.label: A
options.text: Boiling

options.label: B
options.text: Clark's process

options.label: C
options.text: Permutit (ion-exchange) process

options.label: D
options.text: Adding soap

questions.key_concept: Permutit process is used for large-scale softening.

questions.question_text: A student says, 'Adding slaked lime [Ca(OH)2] will soften water containing MgSO4 (permanent hardness).' Is this correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, slaked lime alone is sufficient to precipitate Mg ions as Mg(OH)2.

options.label: B
options.text: No, for MgSO4, both soda ash (Na2CO3) and lime are needed to effectively precipitate Mg as Mg(OH)2 and Ca as CaCO3.

options.label: C
options.text: No, slaked lime makes permanent hardness worse.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but it will make the water acidic.

questions.key_concept: Treatment of permanent hardness due to magnesium salts may require both lime and soda.

questions.question_text: What is the precipitate formed when washing soda is added to water containing calcium sulphate (CaSO4)?

options.label: A
options.text: Calcium carbonate (CaCO3)

options.label: B
options.text: Calcium hydroxide [Ca(OH)2]

options.label: C
options.text: Sodium sulphate (Na2SO4)

options.label: D
options.text: Magnesium carbonate (MgCO3)

questions.key_concept: Reaction of washing soda with calcium sulphate.

questions.question_text: How does the permutit process differ from the washing soda method in terms of the principle used?

options.label: A
options.text: Washing soda: chemical precipitation; Permutit: ion exchange.

options.label: B
options.text: Both use chemical precipitation.

options.label: C
options.text: Washing soda: ion exchange; Permutit: distillation.

options.label: D
options.text: Both are based on boiling.

questions.key_concept: Different softening principles: precipitation vs. ion exchange.

questions.question_text: Why can permutit be regenerated after it becomes inactive?

options.label: A
options.text: By passing a concentrated brine (NaCl) solution through it, which replaces Ca2+/Mg2+ ions with Na+ ions again.

options.label: B
options.text: By boiling it in water.

options.label: C
options.text: By adding washing soda to it.

options.label: D
options.text: It cannot be regenerated; it is discarded.

questions.key_concept: Regeneration of permutit using brine, making the process economical.
